report_title: Database & Directory Publishing in the US
executive_summary: The era of the phone book is over. The catastrophic fall of the Database and Directory Publishing industry between 2019 and 2024 has only been accelerated by the sustained migration from print to digital advertising, as publishers historically made money by selling print ads. Forced to focus on digital presence, the industry has experienced immovable competition from online search engines and social media platforms, limiting the industry's digital advertisement sales. Industry revenue has been eroding at a CAGR of 7.9% over the past five years; it is ultimately expected to total $6.5 billion in 2024, including a projected drop of 2.5% over the year, as directory publishing continues to struggle after the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Directory and database publishers earn modest revenue by selling advertising space to businesses, but this figure has decreased even more after the pandemic. Given that expenditure on print advertising is anticipated to fall at a CAGR of more than 10%, businesses are becoming highly selective in funding print advertisements. Many smaller directories have decided that operating offline ads are not worth their time and have canceled future advertising availability. Instead, they have turned to selling access to aggregated public records.

Rather than visiting a digital directory site to conduct business searches, consumers are increasingly bypassing these sites entirely, opting to perform the same search while on Google or Facebook as a matter of convenience. Search engines and social media sites act as more convenient substitutes for industry services on both the business and consumer fronts. However, social media information tends to focus on what is posted by users and not available from public records. Many consumers are unhappy that these data brokers exist and go to great lengths to pull their personal information off the internet; this has been enabled by the passage of GDPR, among other information storage laws.

Historically, the industry was dominated by a few leading telephone companies, such as AT&T and Verizon; as interest in directory goods and services declined, these companies spun off their publishing businesses to create Thryv as an independent entity. Thryv owns the industry's only remaining household name brands, the Yellow Pages and White Pages. Continued consolidation will act on the largest physical directory publishing companies as revenue and profit continue to fall.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE END OF UNTARGETED PRINT ADVERTISING MAY COME SOON
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although growth in consumer spending and private investment will boost spending on advertisements overall, declining print advertising expenditure will be driven by the continued shift of consumer preferences to digital and online formats. In the coming years, digital media viewership is expected to dominate print readership due in no small part to the COVID-19 pandemic limiting physical media distribution and habituating readers with digital content.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ONLINE DIRECTORIES STARE DOWN INTENSE COMPETITION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As a result, directory operators will be forced to combat intense competition from online search engines and social media companies. Google's dominance in the advertising space, data centers of consumer behavior patterns and ownership of several operating systems have given the company a controlling stake in the ad marketplace alongside Meta (Facebook). As a matter of convenience, more consumers are expected to conduct business searches on Google, Facebook and similar general-interest sites rather than visit a focused digital directory or database to yield similar results. While some searches that can only happen on digital directories will remain on the platform, many companies will spool their own data aggregators if the underlying resource is free and the company needs it often enough.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ONGOING CONSOLIDATION BECOMES MORE FRANTIC, PARTICULARLY IN PRINT MEDIA
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Publishers are anticipated to continue merger and acquisition activity as the leading operators try to boost performance by acquiring smaller competitors with valuable trademarks and patents. As the industry becomes more digitized over the coming years, fewer companies will be involved with publishing physical directories, leading to a more competitive landscape that a few dozen national operators dominate. While consolidation will help decelerate the fall of industry profitability, price pressures will likely continue to erode industry profit gradually.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that publish organized compilations of information or facts. These collections may be published in print or electronic form. Electronic versions can be provided directly to customers by the

positive_impact_factors: high - steady Barriers To Entry Level

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Print advertising expenditure

key_trends: Relative market share in directory publishing is going up as revenue falls. Still, many more companies fail to successfully transition and fade out of the market.
Digital directory companies entering online advertising are competing with Google's ad dominance. Unsurprisingly, no player has managed to build a significant ad network.
Physical phone books are rare, often disliked and expensive to produce. Digital directories and advertising space show some promise for existing companies, but the transition will be rocky at best.

Despite the decline of directories, regulatory change is shifting ever faster. The laws that mandate phone book production are being repealed, while data privacy acts are giving consumers a choice to opt out of being included.

market_segmentation.segment: Advertisers Swap Paper Marketing for Highly Targeted Social Media Ads
market_segmentation.segment_description: Phone book and directory profitability relies heavily on revenue from advertising sales displayed inline or separate pages to subscriber information. As print advertising has continued to fall rapidly, accelerated by the COVID-necessitated halt in phone book production, the industry has more aggressively targeted the benefits for advertisers available via digital promotion.

market_segmentation.segment: Digital Subscriptions Rise, But Remain Extremely Low
market_segmentation.segment_description: People search and database sites have expanded as tools for individuals and businesses, primarily driven by the increasing need for quick access to public records and personal information. These platforms serve as repositories that aggregate data from various sources, allowing users to locate and verify identities, perform background checks and gain insights into demographic profiles.

market_segmentation.segment: Other Sales And Rentals Are Frantic Attempts To Bring In Revenue
market_segmentation.segment_description: As directory services continue to be affected by the shift to digital, operators have strived to offset losses through ancillary services such as mailing list rental and third-party printing, as well as one-time sales to customers that blur the line between corporate clients and consumers.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: PRINT DIRECTORIES CONTINUE TO BECOME MORE EXPENSIVE
demand_determinants.determinant_description: AND LESS USEFUL The focus on consumer convenience has led to the evisceration of print publications, as more consumers are searching for information and conducting various activities online; this has driven information collectors to focus on online publications increasingly.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: ONLINE PUBLICATIONS DOMINATE THE DIRECTORY INDUSTRY
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Online databases of phones and other personal information have become increasingly important for customers as accessible and timely data becomes necessary. This segment's industry share has exploded to over two-thirds of total revenue, beating print directory revenue handily due to the pandemic pushing people online.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest percentage of both business establishments (around 35%) and population (around 30%).
The West region has the second-highest percentage of business establishments (around 20%) and population (around 25%).
The Mid-Atlantic region has a higher percentage of population (around 15%) compared to the percentage of business establishments (around 10%).
The Great Lakes region has a similar percentage of business establishments (around 10%) and population (around 12%).
The Plains region has a lower percentage of both business establishments (around 5%) and population (around 5%).
The Southwest region has a higher percentage of business establishments (around 10%) compared to the population (around 8%).
The Rocky Mountains region has a lower percentage of both business establishments (around 5%) and population (around 3%).
The New England region has a lower percentage of business establishments (around 5%) compared to the population (around 5%).

regulations_points.regulation_description: As landline use fades, phone book and directory publishers will have more difficulty maintaining accurate records. The Federal Communications Commission's 2021 sunset on support for copper telephone technologies has allowed operators to avoid installing new dedicated phone cables.

Introduced and signed in 2021, Michigan's government repealed its longstanding requirement, forcing all landline phone operators to publish directories of subscribers and provide them free of charge on request.

In March 2002, the FCC decided to cap prices to open up competition in the directory publishing industry. The rate was capped at $0.06 per listing for updated details when publishers were looking to charge $0.65 per update.

The industry is subject to a growing number of state privacy laws, including limitations on the improper disclosure of information, the right to inspect information and the right of consumers to forego disclosing their personal information with third parties.

barriers_points.barrier_description: New directory publishers must handle consumer information appropriately, avoid copying information from other directory providers and comply with all regulations on the proper disposal of phone books.

Differentiating is becoming progressively more difficult in the contracting directory publishing industry, and even more so problematic in digital solutions. This barrier is the most important to resolve to be successful.

basis_points.basis_title: Relative market share in directory publishing is going up as revenue falls
basis_points.basis_description: Still, many more companies fail to successfully transition and fade out of the market.

basis_points.basis_title: Digital directory companies entering online advertising are competing with Google's ad dominance
basis_points.basis_description: Unsurprisingly, no player has managed to build a significant ad network.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Database and Directory Publishing industry exhibits a low level of concentration. In 2023, not a single company holds a market share greater than 5.0%, with Thryv Inc. expected to control industry revenue just short of this figure. Relative market share concentration has increased as companies continue exiting the industry or pivot toward developing digital solutions.

The proliferation of digital people search platforms stems from accessibility, cost-effectiveness and the fragmented nature of public records. The barrier to entry for creating an online people search tool is relatively low, given the plethora of available public data and minimal initial capital required.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs are Increasing as the Price of Recycled Paper Rises
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of paper, one of the most significant inputs into industry directories, spiked in 2022 as directory publishers battled increasingly strict environmental regulations and decreased demand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Relative Wage Expenses are Increasing Despite Employment Cratering
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: In 2023, wages are expected to account for 26.2% of industry revenue. Despite slightly increasing compensation, employment has been slashed due to the growing importance of online publications and the lesser need for manual labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Labor intensity is relatively low as database publishers move more online. New database publishers will need layout and advertising specialists to create a usable phone book.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Search engines move revenue towards social media
volatility_points.volatility_description: The dominance of search engines in prioritizing social media profiles over traditional contact information has led to a significant reevaluation of strategies within the phone book and people search industry.
The industry's shift toward online directories unprotected by phone book production mandates has exacerbated the volatility of its revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Attempting a Switch to Data Brokerage Services
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Instead of just collecting subscriber names and phone numbers, some directory companies are buying public records in bulk and reselling them back to consumers.

FAQs.question: How can leveraging advanced analytics in customer segmentation and targeting amplify your ROI in database and directory publishing?
FAQs.answer: Advanced analytics go beyond traditional demographics, allowing for a hyper-personalized approach to sales and marketing. By leveraging advanced analytics, you can segment your customer base into highly targeted groups and tailor your marketing efforts accordingly, resulting in higher engagement, conversion rates, and ultimately, a better return on investment.

FAQs.question: What strategies can be employed to integrate user-generated content (UGC) to boost credibility and engagement in your published directories?
FAQs.answer: Incorporating UGC, such as reviews and recommendations, into your directories enhances the richness and credibility of your content. This can improve engagement levels as potential users often trust peer opinions over traditional advertising. Strategically, this could involve developing platforms for users to easily submit content, coupled with incentives for participation.

FAQs.question: How can optimizing your content delivery platforms according to changing consumer behavior patterns impact your operational efficiency?
FAQs.answer: As consumer preferences shift towards mobile and on-demand access, publishers must adapt their content delivery platforms accordingly. By aligning operations with evolving consumption patterns, publishers can achieve greater operational efficiency through reduced bounce rates, higher retention, and streamlined content delivery systems. Adopting agile content management systems that can pivot based on analytics will ensure effective resource allocation.

FAQs.question: In what ways can cross-functional team collaboration within database and directory publishing companies drive innovation and operational excellence?
FAQs.answer: Cross-functional collaboration breaks down silos between departments, fostering a culture of shared goals and mutual understanding. This collaborative approach can lead to innovative solutions that propel the company forward. For instance, IT and marketing teams working together can quickly deploy new technologies tailored to customer needs, enhancing user experience and driving engagement.

FAQs.question: How can artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) algorithms transform data accuracy and user experience in online directories?
FAQs.answer: Implementing AI and ML algorithms can revolutionize how publishers manage and present data. These technologies can automate data cleansing and updating, ensuring high accuracy and reliability. For users, this translates to a smoother experience with quicker access to relevant information. AI can also personalize user interactions, predicting and presenting the most relevant results.

FAQs.question: How does the integration of advanced search functionalities, powered by natural language processing (NLP), enhance discoverability and user engagement in database and directory services?
FAQs.answer: Natural language processing enables directories to understand and process user queries in everyday language, making the search process intuitive and efficient. This allows publishers to offer sophisticated search capabilities, where users can find precise information without complex query languages. By analyzing search trends and user interactions, publishers can gain valuable insights into user needs.

FAQs.question: How can staying ahead of global data protection regulations give database and directory publishing companies a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: Proactively adhering to stringent data privacy standards, such as the GDPR, can reassure users and stakeholders of a commitment to data security, enhancing brand reputation. This preemptive approach can open doors to global markets sensitive to data privacy, providing a competitive edge over less compliant rivals. Demonstrating leadership in ethical data use can attract partnerships.

FAQs.question: What role does adherence to accessibility standards play?
FAQs.answer: Ensuring digital content meets accessibility standards is not just about compliance; it's a strategic advantage. Implementing web content accessibility guidelines (WCAG) makes directories usable to a wider audience, including those with disabilities, widening the potential user base. Embracing accessibility can bolster a company's social responsibility profile, impacting brand perception and customer loyalty positively.

FAQs.question: In what ways can dynamic pricing strategies maximize?
FAQs.answer: Dynamic pricing, which adjusts prices based on demand, competition, and other factors, offers a powerful tool for maximizing revenue. By analyzing user behavior, market trends, and content consumption patterns, publishers can identify optimal pricing strategies for different audience segments. This approach enhances revenue potential through tailored pricing and helps in cultivating more lucrative market segments.

FAQs.question: How can financial modeling based on predictive analytics influence strategic decision-making in the database and directory publishing industry?
FAQs.answer: Predictive analytics provides a forward-looking view, enabling publishers to anticipate market shifts, user behavior changes, and evolving revenue streams. By incorporating predictive analytics into financial modeling, companies can forecast future financial scenarios with greater accuracy, informing strategic decisions around content development, marketing investments, and operational adjustments.
